entry.title: Cloud Integration - Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX using the SAP LeanIX Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

As IT landscapes expand across cloud platforms, regions, and teams, transparency and governance become just as important as connectivity. Knowing that systems are connected is not enough, you also need to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture.

A very common example of this challenge can be seen with SAP BTP. Organizations start with a few Global and Subaccounts for specific projects, but over time the landscape grows. New subaccounts are created for pilots, innovations, regional teams, and temporary initiatives. Months later, questions start surfacing:

  • How many SAP BTP accounts do we actually have?
  • Which ones are actively used versus idle?
  • Who is responsible for each account?
  • How do these technical setups align with business capabilities and strategy?

Without a structured approach to documentation and governance, SAP BTP landscapes can quickly lose clarity which makes audits, cost optimization, and strategic decisions difficult.

This is where Enterprise Architecture Management and tools like LeanIX play a crucial role.

What is SAP LeanIX?

SAP LeanIX is a Enterprise Architecture (EA) and IT Portfolio Management solution that helps companies visualize, analyze, and modernize their IT landscapes.

Key Functions & Benefits:

  • Application Portfolio Management (APM): Creates clear, up-to-date application inventories to identify redundancies and reduce tech debt.
  • Roadmap & Architecture Planning: Aligns IT strategy with business goals, planning future landscapes for changes like cloud migrations or AI.
  • Transformation Guidance: Helps navigate complex projects, such as ERP (SAP S/4HANA), mergers, and SaaS adoption.
  • IT Risk Management: Manages technology obsolescence and compliance risks, notes the SAP Help Portal.
  • Business Capability Mapping: Connects business processes to underlying applications and technology. 

LeanIX focuses heavily on data-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but living documentation.

Understanding Fact Sheets in LeanIX

Fact Sheets are the core building blocks of LeanIX. They are structured data objects used to represent key elements of your enterprise architecture, such as applications, IT components, interfaces, business capabilities, organizations, and technical platforms.

Each Fact Sheet captures:

  • Essential metadata (name, lifecycle, status)
  • Relationships between architecture elements
  • Ownership and responsibility information

Fact Sheets act as a single source of truth for your architecture landscape.

Why Fact Sheets Matter

Fact Sheets help you:

  • Move away from Excel-based documentation
  • Keep architecture data consistent and up to date
  • Visualize dependencies and impact
  • Support audits, compliance, and informed decision-making

In this blog, we will use Fact Sheets to represent SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

Integration Scenario Overview

In this scenario, we build an integration that provides end-to-end visibility of SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

The integration flow performs the following steps:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CI) retrieves details of:
    • SAP BTP Global Accounts
    • SAP BTP Subaccounts
  • The retrieved data is transformed into a LeanIX-compatible structure
  • LeanIX Fact Sheets are then created or updated using the LeanIX Adapter, ensuring the information in LeanIX remains consistent and up to date

This integration is based on SAP Standard Integration Content available in the Discover tab of SAP Cloud Integration/SAP Business Accelerator hub https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure . Since the core flow is already provided by SAP, this blog does not cover every palette or step in detail.

The focus is on a key enhancement:
the standard content uses an HTTP adapter to communicate with LeanIX, which has been updated to use the native LeanIX Adapter to meet the use case.

Why Integrate SAP BTP with LeanIX?

As SAP BTP landscapes grow across regions, teams, and projects, maintaining governance becomes challenging. Without visibility, organizations risk unused subaccounts, unclear ownership, and compliance issues. Integrating SAP BTP with LeanIX ensures architecture data stays up to date, provides real-time visibility, and enables informed, data-driven decisions.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration

SAP Cloud Integration provides a native LeanIX Adapter, making it easier to interact with LeanIX APIs without building everything from scratch.

  • Supports GraphQL variant that allows you to manage FactSheets using standard operations like Create, Get, Update etc.
  • GraphQL variant allows you to specify requirements using Advanced Query feature.
  • Supports REST variant to manage entities like Bookmarks and Settings using CRUD operations.
  • Offers secure authentication via LeanIX OAuth option which employs OAuth authentication.

SAP LeanIX Setup:

Lets start with creating a technical User on LeanIX , because we need the API token to interact with the application

Step 1: In the user profile menu, select Administration, and then go to Technical Users.

Step 2: Create a new Technical User.

Step 3: As soon as you create a technical user, an API Token is generated. Make sure the token is saved as it displays only once

Now, we are all good on Lean IX end.

Deploy this token as a Secure Parameter under Security Artifact in SAP CI

Configurations on SAP BTP.

We make use of SAP BTP Core Services APIs to fetch details of SAP BTP accounts. To enable this, a SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) instance must be created in the SAP BTP subaccount.

For a detailed, step-by-step guide on:

  • Creating a service instance and service key for CIS
  • Configuring OAuth credentials in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Configuring HTTP Adapter to fetch the information of the SAP BTP Accounts

Please refer to the following blog: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

SAP CI IFlow:

As mentioned above, the iflow design is referenced from an existing iflow present on Discover tab, you can also locate this on SAP Business Accelerator Hub : https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure 

Request Body to create Level 1 Factsheet:

{
  "query": "mutation ($input: BaseFactSheetInput!, $patches: [Patch]!) { createFactSheet(input: $input, patches: $patches) { factSheet { id name type ... on Platform { description name } } } }",
  "variables": {
    "input": {
      "name": "Trail SAP BTP Account",
      "type": "Platform"
    },
    "patches": [
      {
        "op": "add",
        "path": "/description",
        "value": "Global Account FactSheet created automatically by SAP Integration Suite."
      }
    ]
  }
}

In this updated version, I have used LeanIX adapter to connect to LeanIX system, the configuration of LeanIX Adapter is shown below.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP CI has two variants, In this design GraphQL Variant is used

Configuration of LeanIX Adapter

Connection Tab:

 
Parameter
Value
Comments
Address
https://<<domain>>.leanix.net
SAP LeanIX endpoint
Authentication
LeanIX OAuth
To use LeanIX API Token for authentication
API Token Alias
LeanIX
Secure Parameter which was created in the steps above
Reuse Connection
Yes/No
Enable if the connection needs to be reused
Connection Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) while establishing a connection with LeanIX
Respone Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) ) for a response to be received from LeanIX.
 

Processing Tab:

The Objective is create Factsheet on LeanIX, Configure the operation and entity as shown below

All set! lets go for the demo now.

Demo:

We are all set on SAP BTP, SAP CI and LeanIX end. Lets deploy the iflow and check the results.

SAP BTP Account:

This is how the SAP BTP account is structured. Now lets check how the Fact Sheets  are created on the LeanIX side.

SAP LeanIX:

The data is successfully integrated in LeanIX and Factsheets are created.

SAP BTP Account was one global Account and 3 Subaccounts,

Factsheet 1: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account

Factsheet 2: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account and there are 3 Subaccounts linked to it (shown as 3 children), You can also see all the relevant tags like ‚ÄúTRAIL‚Äù, ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù

 

Factsheet 3: This sheet talks about the subaccount ‚ÄúDevelopment‚Äù, it is linked to the Parent Factsheet which is related to the Global Account

Similarly there are two more factsheets for Quality and Production Subaccounts, In total creating 5 Factsheets on SAP LeanIX

With this integration in place, SAP BTP account data is no longer just operational information, it becomes architectural knowledge. By synchronizing SAP BTP Global and Subaccount details into LeanIX Fact Sheets using SAP Cloud Integration and the LeanIX Adapter, we establish a single, governed view of the cloud landscape.

What was previously scattered across platforms is now visible, structured, and actionable. Architects and stakeholders can clearly understand ownership, lifecycle, and usage of SAP BTP accounts without manual documentation or spreadsheets.

But this is only the beginning.

What More Can Be Done?

This opens up several powerful possibilities beyond basic Fact Sheet creation:

  • Maintain relationships between Fact Sheets
    (e.g., linking BTP accounts to applications, integrations, or business capabilities)
  • Enrich Fact Sheets with custom attributes such as cost center, environment, or compliance tags
  • Synchronize lifecycle states automatically based on real usage
  • Detect and manage redundancies across accounts and platforms
  • Enable impact analysis by visualizing dependencies across your architecture

By combining runtime integration data with enterprise architecture governance, LeanIX transforms Fact Sheets from static records into living architecture assets.

 

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.title: Working with CDS I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor For Cloud Development (SAP S4HANA Public Cloud)
entry.content:
Note : This Blog contains parts of SAP standard documentation and my point of observation.

I_APISWITHCLOUDDEVSUCCESSOR :  APIs with Cloud Development Successors.

Apart from the Business accelerator hub   or Cloudification Repository Viewer  you would have heard from your fellow developers that there is a CDS view available in the SAP Public cloud system to check for the released and available cloud development ready objects . Here comes the I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor CDS view , using this CDS view you can get all the cloud ready objects (Business objects , Latest API ) for the existing objects (Tables , CDS)  . 

Existing SAP Standard code:

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_ALLOWED
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@EndUserText.label: 'APIs with Cloud Development Successors'
define view entity I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
  // Option 1: Predecessor has one or more successors for cloud development
  as select from ars_w_api_state               as predecessor
    inner join   ARS_API_SUCCESSORS_FOR_C1_SCP as successor           on  predecessor.object_type     = successor.tadir_object
                                                                      and predecessor.object_name     = successor.tadir_obj_name
                                                                      and predecessor.sub_object_type = successor.object_type
                                                                      and predecessor.sub_object_name = successor.object_key
    inner join   ARS_RUNTIME_API_STATE         as cloud_dev_successor on  cloud_dev_successor.object_type               = successor.successor_tadir_object
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.object_name               = successor.successor_tadir_obj_name
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.sub_object_type           = successor.successor_object_type
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.sub_object_name           = successor.successor_object_key
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X'  // Use in cloud development
                                                                      and cloud_dev_successor.release_state             = 'RELEASED'
  association [0..1] to v_ars_release_state as _text on _text.state = predecessor.release_state
{
  key predecessor.sub_object_type                         as PredecessorObjectType,
  key predecessor.sub_object_name                         as PredecessorObjectName,
  key predecessor.object_type                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key predecessor.object_name                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
  key successor.successor_object_type                     as SuccessorObjectType,
  key successor.successor_object_key                      as SuccessorObjectName,
  key successor.successor_tadir_object                    as SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key successor.successor_tadir_obj_name                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      predecessor.successor_concept_name                  as SuccessorConceptName,
      cast('O' as ars_successor_category preserving type) as SuccessorCategory, // Object
      predecessor.release_state                           as PredecessorReleaseState,
      _text.description                                   as PredecessorReleaseStateDescr
}
where
       predecessor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
  and  predecessor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X' // Use in cloud development
  and(
       predecessor.successor_classification  = '1' // One object
    or predecessor.successor_classification  = 'N' // Multiple objects
  )

// Option 2: Predecessor was replaced by a concept
union select from ars_w_api_state as predecessor
association [0..1] to v_ars_release_state as _text on _text.state = predecessor.release_state
{
  key predecessor.sub_object_type                         as PredecessorObjectType,
  key predecessor.sub_object_name                         as PredecessorObjectName,
  key predecessor.object_type                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key predecessor.object_name                             as PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectType,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectName,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
  key ''                                                  as SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      predecessor.successor_concept_name                  as SuccessorConceptName,
      cast('C' as ars_successor_category preserving type) as SuccessorCategory, // Concept
      predecessor.release_state                           as PredecessorReleaseState,
      _text.description                                   as PredecessorReleaseStateDescr
}
where
      predecessor.compatibility_contract    = 'C1' // System-internal use
  and predecessor.use_in_sap_cloud_platform = 'X' // Use in cloud development
  and predecessor.successor_classification  = 'X' // Concept

  The view I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor returns development objects which themselves either cannot be used or should no longer be used in cloud development, together with one or more successors that can be used instead.

A successor can be one of the following:

  1. a development object that was released as API for system-internal use (contract C1) and visibility Use in Cloud Development, as specified in the ABAP Development Tools, using the API State tab of the Properties view
  2. a concept which replaces the development object.

The predecessor and successor objects returned by this view are identified by their object type and name.
In most cases, object type and name are identical with the respective object directory type and name.
Exceptions from this rule are the following:

Description Object Type Object Name Object Directory Type Object Directory Name

CDS EntityCDS_STOB<CDS Entity Name>DDLS<Data Definition Name>
BAdI DefinitionBADI_DEF<BAdI Definition Name>ENHS<Enhancement Spot Name>
Function ModuleFUNC<Function Module Name>FUGR<Function Group Name>

SAP Released ABAP Object Types :

You might not find every type , but more and more objects are getting added after every release.

 

APIS

API Release State of Objects

APLO

Application Log Object

AUTH

Authorization Check Fields

BDEF

Behavior Definition

BGQC

Background Processing Context

CDBO

Customer Data Browser Object

CFDF

Custom Field

CHDO

Change Document

CHKC

ATC Check Category

CHKO

ATC Check Object

CHKV

ATC Check Variant

CLAS

Class

COTA

Connection Target Transport Object

DCLS

ABAP Data Control Language Sources

DDLS

Data Definition Language Source

DDLX

Core Data Services Metadata Extensions

DEVC

Package

DESD

Logical External Schema

DOMA

Domain

DRAS

CDS Aspects

DRTY

Dictionary: CDS Type Definitions

DSFD

CDS Scalar Function Definition

DSFI

CDS Scalar Function Implementation Reference

DTEB

Dictionary Tuning: Entities Buffer

DTEL

Data Element

EEEC

Event Consumption Modell

ENHO

Enhancement Implementation Object

ENHS

Enhancement Spot Object

EVTB

Event Binding

ENQU

Lock Object

FUGR

FUNC

Function Module

GSMP

Metric Provider

HTTP

HTTP Service

INTF

Interface

INTM

Intelligent Scenario Model

INTS

Intelligent Scenario

MSAG

Message Class

NONT

SAP Object Node Type

NTTY

Note Type

NROB

Number Range Object

RONT

SAP Object Type

SAJC

Application Job Catalog Entry

SAJT

Application Job Template

SCO1

Communication: Communication Scenario

SCO2

Communication: Inbound Service

SCO3

Outbound Service

SIA1

IAM: Business Catalog

SIA2

IAM: Restriction Type

SIA3

IAM: Authorization Object Extension

SIA5

IAM: Restriction Field

SIA6

IAM: App

SIA7

IAM: Business Catalog App Assignment

SIA8

IAM: Business Role Template

SIA9

IAM: Business Role Templ. Bus. Catalog Assignment

SIAD

Business Role Template Fiori Space Assignment

SKTD

Knowledge Transfer Document

SMBC

Maintainable Business Configuration

SOD1

API Package

SOD2

API Package Assignment

SRVD

Service Definition

SUSH

Assignment: Service --> Authorization Objects

SUSO

Authorization Object

SWCR

TABL

TTYP

Table Type

UIAD

Application Descriptors for the Fiori Launchpad Enviornment

UIPG

Fiori Launchpad Page Template

UIST

Fiori Launchpad Space Template

XSLT

Transformation

Field Explanations : 

PredecessorObjectType

Object type of the predecessor object which cannot be used or should no longer be used

PredecessorObjectName

Name of the predecessor object which cannot be used or should no longer be used

PredecessorObjectDirectoryType

Object type of the predecessor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJECT)

PredecessorObjectDirectoryName

Name of the predecessor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJ_NAME)

SuccessorObjectType

Object type of the successor object

SuccessorObjectName

Name of the successor object

SuccessorObjectDirectoryType

Object type of the successor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJECT)

SuccessorObjectDirectoryName

Name of the successor object in the object directory (TABL:TADIR.OBJ_NAME)

SuccessorConceptName

Name of the concept which replaces the predecessor object

SuccessorCategory

Indicates whether the successor is a released development object or a concept

Allowed values are:

  • 'O': released development object
  • 'C': concept

PredecessorReleaseState

Release state of the predecessor object

Allowed values are:

  • 'NOT_TO_BE_RELEASED': The object will not be released and thus cannot be used.
  • 'DEPRECATED': The object was formerly released but is now deprecated and thus should no longer be used.

PredecessorReleaseStateDescr

Language-dependent description of the PredecessorReleaseState

 

What I have done to this CDS view to make it more readable and Provide sense to my Peers :

I have written the following code and exposed the CDS in a service and deployed the same as an APP for my junior collogues to refer and learn easily and this is always in the Dev environment as a Tile.

Note : I know that cloudification repository does exist but sometimes , its easier to guide peers with internal tools . I always love creating objects for internal use üôÇ  .

Code : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'APIs With Cloud Development Successors'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
  as select from I_APIsWithCloudDevSuccessor
{
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 1  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 1  } ]
  key PredecessorObjectName,

      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectType,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Directory Type'
      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectDirectoryType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Directory Name'
      .hidden: true
  key PredecessorObjectDirectoryName,
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 3  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 3  } ]
  key SuccessorObjectName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Directory Type'
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectDirectoryType,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Directory Name'
      .hidden: true
  key SuccessorObjectDirectoryName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Concept Name'
      .identification: [ {  position: 5  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 5  } ]
      SuccessorConceptName,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Category'
      .identification: [ {  position: 6  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 6 } ]
      case SuccessorCategory
      when 'O' then  'Object'
      when 'C' then 'Concept'
      end as SuccessorCategory,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Release State'
      .identification: [ {  position: 7  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 7 , criticality: 'PredecessorReleaseState' ,criticalityRepresentation: #WITH_ICON } ]
      PredecessorReleaseStateDescr,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Release State'
      .hidden: true
      case when PredecessorReleaseState = 'DEPRECATED' then 1
      when PredecessorReleaseState = 'NOT_TO_BE_RELEASED' then 2
      end as PredecessorReleaseState,

      @EndUserText.label: 'Predecessor Object Type'
      .identification: [ {  position: 2  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 2  } ]
      case
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'FUNC' then 'Function Module'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'BADI_DEF' then 'BADI Definition'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'CDS_STOB' then 'CDS-Core Data Services Runtime Object'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      when PredecessorObjectType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      end as PredecessorObjectTypeDesc,
      @EndUserText.label: 'Successor Object Type'
      .identification: [ {  position: 4  } ]
      .lineItem: [ {  position: 4  } ]
      case
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'FUNC' then 'Function Module'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'BADI_DEF' then 'BADI Definition'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'CDS_STOB' then 'CDS-Core Data Services Runtime Object'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      when SuccessorObjectType = 'BDEF' then 'Behavior Definition'
      end as SuccessorObjectTypeDesc


      //      case
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'CHKV' then 'ATC Check Variant'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'CLAS' then 'Class'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DDLS' then 'CDS-Data Definition Language Source'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DOMA' then 'Domain'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'DTEL' then 'Data Element'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'ENHS' then 'BADI Enhancement'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'FDT0' then 'FDT/BRFplus: System Application'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'FUGR' then 'Function Group'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'INTF' then 'Interface'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'SIA2' then 'IAM: Restriction Type'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'SUSO' then 'Authorization Object'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'TABL' then 'Table Definition'
      //        when PredecessorObjectDirectoryType = 'TTYP' then 'Table Type'
      //        end                                                                                                     as PredeObjectDirectoryTypeDesc,

      //      concat_with_space( $projection.PredecessorObjectTypeDesc , $projection.PredeObjectDirectoryTypeDesc , 1 ) as PredecessorObjectType2
}

Sample screenshot of the APP :  

 

 

Note : This Blog is created solely with my experience and learning from SAP , This Blog does contain parts of SAP Standard documentation available in the SAP S4HANA Public cloud. Since the documentation is not available to each user , I have Included the same . If the information shared in the blog is misleading or should be removed / corrected , please let me know in the comments .

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management ‚Äì Part 4 (New Feature)
entry.content:
Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

In this blog part, I‚Äôll dive into a major breakthrough released in December 2025: the ability to support N:N integration scenarios in Multiple Company integration scenario between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Field Management.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Part 4 - Multi-Company Integration: Scaling Across LoBs and Source Systems

Previously, integrating master data from multiple source systems or Line of Businesses (LoBs) or Regions into multiple SAP FSM companies was a technical bottleneck. The standard integration content relied on a single Multiple Company Value Mapping artifact to manage company determination. This meant you couldn't easily maintain distinct mapping rules for different regions, or LoBs, or S/4HANA systems within a single SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) tenant.

This limitation is now a thing of the past.

Enabling N:N Integration via Value Mapping Prefixes

The latest update introduces a flexible strategy to support multiple S/4HANA sources or LoBs, each requiring its own unique multi-company mapping criteria. By using a Value Mapping Prefix, you can now deploy distinct mapping rules side-by-side in the same environment.

How it Works

  • Unique Identifiers: You can now assign a unique prefix (e.g., LOB1_ or REGION_A_) to your multiple company Value Mapping artifacts.
  • Independent Artifacts: Instead of one giant mapping table, the system creates separate, dedicated artifacts (e.g., LOB1_AccountCompany) for each specific source or business unit.
  • End-to-End Consistency: By configuring this prefix across all relevant integration flows, you ensure that data from Source A always follows Rule A, and Source B always follows Rule B.

Configuration Steps: How to Set It Up

To enable this, a new external parameter, ValueMappingPrefix, has been added to the standard suite of interfaces.

  1. Update Your Interfaces

You must configure the prefix value in the following standard iFlows to ensure they recognize the specific mapping rules for that LoB:

  • Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping Configuration
  • Replicate Business Partner (and Contacts/Relationships)
  • Replicate Products, Product Stock, and Product Price
  • Replicate Item Groups
  • Replicate Service Orders (SOAP)
  1. Practical Example

If you are setting up integration for "Line of Business 1":

  • Configure the Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping iFlow with the prefix LOB1_.
  • Deploy the iFlow. This automatically generates a new artifact named: LOB1_Value Mapping for Multiple Company determination in SAP FSM from SAP S4HANA.
  • Now, all data tagged with LOB1_ will use these specific rules, keeping your global configuration clean and organized.

  • Once your multi-company configuration has been synchronized to SAP Cloud Integration, you are ready to configure and deploy the master data iFlows. Ensure you specify the correct ValueMappingPrefix in each interface to route data accurately from S/4HANA to FSM, as shown in the example below:

Best Practices for Implementation

Pro Tip: To keep your integration landscape manageable, copy the standard package (‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management‚Äù) for each distinct LoB.

For each copied package:

  • Assign the unique prefix consistently across all iFlows within that package.
  • Synchronize sequentially: Update your mapping configuration in S/4HANA for one LoB at a time, then deploy the corresponding synchronization iFlow to push those rules to CPI.

Summary of Benefits

  • Scalability: Manage multiple S/4HANA systems in a single CPI tenant without data collisions.
  • Flexibility: Define region-specific or business-unit-specific rules for how data maps to FSM companies.
  • Reduced Complexity: No need for multiple CPI tenants to handle different business segments.

 

Note: This is an advanced configuration intended specifically for N:N integration scenarios (multiple source systems to multiple FSM companies) within a single SAP Cloud Integration tenant. By default, the ValueMappingPrefix is blank, supporting the standard 1:N integration (single S/4HANA source to multiple FSM companies).

entry.title: Re: Select package size to solve 'Time out' Dump.
entry.content:
It works well. I can see in SM50 that the duration restarts from 0 after each SAPGUI_PROGRESS_INDICATOR. In the code below, it can work without WITH HOLD.

OPEN CURSOR @DATA(cursor) FOR
  SELECT *
    FROM ekpo.

DATA itab TYPE TABLE OF ekpo.
DATA(percentage) = 0.
DO.

  FETCH NEXT CURSOR @cursor
  INTO TABLE @itab
  PACKAGE SIZE 18000.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  percentage += 1.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SAPGUI_PROGRESS_INDICATOR'
    EXPORTING percentage = percentage
              text       = 'In progress'.

ENDDO.
CLOSE CURSOR cursor.

NB: the popup cannot be displayed between OPEN CURSOR and CLOSE CURSOR, a short dump DBSQL_INVALID_CURSOR would be raised at the next FETCH.

The class CL_PROGRESS_INDICATOR may be used in case the code is to operate in either dialog or background mode (in dialog, it will call the function module).

Tests with ABAP 7.58 and HANA

entry.title: Re: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
This has caught us out today. In our app, we specify the url for openui5 as part of our html page. All of a sudden, today, our app stopped working for all of our customers. We specify in our server that the openui5 location is allowed as far as security policy is concerned, but because the old url does a redirect to the new url, the new url violates the security policy. Hence all of our customers suddenly could no longer load our app. 

Although it seems like a simple redirect, it is not as simple as that and it took quite a bit of tracking down as to what broke. Once we found this article, we were able to get up and running again by changing the url to the new one. However, a bit more notice and a more prominent article would have been helpful to have prevented the downtime for our customers.

entry.title: Re: T169G is not reporting the same values entered in OMR...
entry.content:
Why the mismatch occurs is because of the following:

  • OMR6: You maintain tolerance limits for invoice verification in a given currency.
  • TCURX: This table defines decimal places for currencies. For IDR (Indonesian Rupiah), SAP standard sets 0 decimals.
  • T169G: Stores the tolerance values. However, internally SAP always keeps amounts in two decimal places (like ‚Äúcurrency with cents‚Äù), even if TCURX says 0 decimals.

So when you enter ‚Äú4,000,000 IDR‚Äù in OMR6, the system converts it into the internal representation with 2 decimals. In T169G, you‚Äôll see ‚Äú40,000.00‚Äù (effectively scaled down by 100). That‚Äôs why you see the value expressed in thousands with decimals ‚Äî it‚Äôs not wrong, it‚Äôs how SAP stores it internally.

So to overcome from this, you just have to enter values in OMR6 considering the scaling. For example, if you want a tolerance of 4,000,000 IDR, you must enter 40000 in OMR6 (because internally SAP multiplies by 100).

entry.title: Re: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
This change broke all of our UI5 applications across all customer landscapes at once. Because we rely on SAP-provided CDN resources, our customers experienced outages that were completely outside of their control and ours.

The biggest issue is loss of customer trust. When applications stop working due to an unannounced or insufficiently communicated infrastructure change from SAP, customers don‚Äôt see this as a ‚ÄúCDN update‚Äù they see it as our application being unreliable. This damages confidence in partners and implementers who are building on SAP‚Äôs officially recommended resources.

Changes of this nature must be treated as breaking changes, with prominent communication, long transition periods, and clear migration guidance. Otherwise, the operational and reputational cost is unfairly pushed onto customers and partners.
